verses.text: At that time Abijah, the son of Jeroboam, became sick.
verses.comment: Text closely follows the Hebrew: sets the scene for Jeroboam’s family crisis.

verses.text: Jeroboam said to his wife, 'Please get up and disguise yourself, so that no one will know you are Jeroboam’s wife. Go to Shiloh. Look, Ahijah the prophet is there—the one who told me I would be king over this people.'
verses.comment: Paraphrase matches the original sense; included exact names and places for clarity.

verses.text: 'Take with you ten loaves, some cakes, and a jar of honey, and go to him. He will tell you what will happen to the boy.'
verses.comment: Supplies mentioned are named plainly.

verses.text: Jeroboam’s wife did so, she got up and went to Shiloh, and came to the house of Ahijah. But Ahijah could not see, for his eyes were dim because of his old age.
verses.comment: “Eyes were dim” is a literal translation from the Hebrew text.

verses.text: Now the LORD had said to Ahijah, 'See, the wife of Jeroboam is coming to ask you about her son, for he is sick. Say this and this to her. When she comes, she will pretend to be someone else.'
verses.comment: Preserves ‘Say this and this,’ which is a Hebrew idiom for specific instructions.

verses.text: As soon as Ahijah heard the sound of her feet when she came in at the door, he said, 'Come in, wife of Jeroboam! Why do you pretend to be someone else? I have been sent to you with hard news.'
verses.comment: “Heard the sound of her feet”—literal rendering. ‘Hard news’ for “harsh” or “difficult message.”

verses.text: Go, tell Jeroboam, ‘This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: I raised you up from among the people and made you leader over my people Israel.’
verses.comment: Retains the unique phrasing referring to God’s sovereign choice.

verses.text: 'I tore the kingdom away from the house of David and gave it to you. But you have not been like my servant David, who kept my commandments and followed me with all his heart, doing only what was right in my eyes.'
verses.comment: “Tore the kingdom away”—captures the Hebrew verb.

verses.text: 'But you have done more evil than all who were before you. You have made for yourself other gods and cast images to provoke me to anger, and you have thrown me behind your back.'
verses.comment: “Thrown me behind your back”—kept literal translation for force.

verses.text: 'Therefore I am bringing disaster on the house of Jeroboam. I will cut off every male, both slave and free, from Jeroboam in Israel. I will sweep away the house of Jeroboam as one sweeps away dung until it is all gone.'
verses.comment: ‘Male’ is literal 'one who urinates against a wall.' ‘Sweep away dung’ is a Hebrew image retained.

verses.text: 'Anyone belonging to Jeroboam who dies in the city, the dogs will eat, and anyone who dies in the field, the birds of the air will eat; for the LORD has spoken it.'
verses.comment: ‘The LORD has spoken’ is a solemn formula retained.

verses.text: 'So get up and go to your house. When your feet enter the city, the child will die.'
verses.comment: Preserves the direct address as in Hebrew.

verses.text: 'All Israel will mourn for him and bury him, for he alone of Jeroboam’s family will be buried, because only in him did something pleasing to the LORD, the God of Israel, be found.'
verses.comment: ‘Something pleasing’ preserves Hebrew idiom ‘found some good thing toward the LORD.’

verses.text: 'The LORD will raise up for himself a king over Israel who will cut off the house of Jeroboam. This day! And even now.'
verses.comment: ‘This day! And even now’ expresses urgency as in Hebrew (Hebrew ‘and what, even now!’).

verses.text: 'And the LORD will strike Israel, as a reed is shaken in the water, and uproot Israel from this good land he gave to their fathers, and scatter them beyond the Euphrates River, because they have made their Asherah poles, provoking the LORD to anger.'
verses.comment: ‘Reed shaken in the water’ and ‘Asherah poles’ kept literally.

verses.text: 'He will give up Israel because of the sins Jeroboam has committed and made Israel to commit.'
verses.comment: ‘Give up’ is literal for ‘abandon’ (Hebrew root: נטש).

verses.text: Then Jeroboam’s wife got up and left, and came to Tirzah. As she came to the threshold of the house, the boy died.
verses.comment: Follows the original order and geography.

verses.text: They buried him, and all Israel mourned for him, as the LORD had said through his servant Ahijah the prophet.
verses.comment: Retains the formula ‘as the LORD had said.’

verses.text: The rest of the acts of Jeroboam, how he fought and how he reigned, see, they are written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Acts’ and ‘The Book of the Chronicles’ kept literal per Hebrew usage.

verses.text: Jeroboam reigned twenty-two years. Then he rested with his fathers, and Nadab his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: ‘Rested with his fathers’ is Hebrew idiom for death.

verses.text: Now Rehoboam, son of Solomon, reigned in Judah. Rehoboam was forty-one years old when he became king, and he reigned seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city the LORD had chosen out of all the tribes of Israel to put his name there. His mother’s name was Naamah, the Ammonite.
verses.comment: Rehoboam’s age and maternal ancestry included for completeness.

verses.text: Judah did evil in the sight of the LORD. They provoked him to jealous anger by their sins, more than all their ancestors had done.
verses.comment: ‘Provoked him to jealous anger’ used for Hebrew ‘made him jealous with their sins.’

verses.text: For they also built for themselves high places, sacred pillars, and Asherah poles on every high hill and under every green tree.
verses.comment: ‘High places,’ ‘sacred pillars,’ and ‘Asherah poles’ retain historical terms; ‘under every green tree’ is a direct translation.

verses.text: And there were male cult prostitutes in the land. They did according to all the abominations of the nations that the LORD drove out before the children of Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Male cult prostitutes’ is literal, matching Hebrew 'qadeshim.'

verses.text: In the fifth year of King Rehoboam, Shishak king of Egypt came up against Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Names and dates preserved exactly.

verses.text: He took away the treasures of the house of the LORD and the treasures of the king’s house. He took away everything. He also took all the shields of gold that Solomon had made.
verses.comment: Clarity added: ‘He took away everything’ for emphasis per Hebrew.

verses.text: King Rehoboam made shields of bronze to replace them, and gave them to the captains of the guard who kept the door of the king’s house.
verses.comment: Paraphrased with literal terms; ‘bronze’ replaces ‘gold’—historical accuracy.

verses.text: Whenever the king entered the house of the LORD, the guards carried those shields, and afterward brought them back to the guard chamber.
verses.comment: Actions described literally, following the original text.

verses.text: The rest of the acts of Rehoboam, and all that he did, are written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Judah.
verses.comment: ‘Book of the Chronicles’ is not the same as 1 & 2 Chronicles; included to match original.

verses.text: There was continual war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam.
verses.comment: ‘Continual war’ clarifies the ongoing conflict of the period.

verses.text: Rehoboam rested with his fathers and was buried with his ancestors in the city of David. His mother’s name was Naamah the Ammonite. And Abijam his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: Repeated mention of Rehoboam’s mother—matches original text for emphasis.
